Comparison and Contrast of Theoretical Perspectives on Perception and Action in Intelligent Agents:

1. Neural Networks and 'Intuitive' Inference ([1] NatureDeepReview.pdf, 2025)
   - These networks use large activity vectors, weight matrices, and scalar non-linearities to perform fast, intuitive inference that underpins commonsense reasoning. (No explicit event year stated; described in 2025 PDF [1])

2. Bayesian Networks and Rule Bases ([3] 1304.1106v1.pdf, 1990)
   - Several different types of experiments have been conducted to compare Bayes nets with rule bases, addressing the behavior of a system. (1990; described in 1990 PDF [3])

3. Simplified Prolog (SP) System ([6] 0311031v1.pdf, 2018)
   - This system is notable for its simplicity and wide scope, possibly wider than most artificial intelligence systems. (2018; described in 2018 PDF [6])

4. Turing Test and Its Variants ([4] 0712.3329v1.pdf, 2007)
   - The Turing test and its many variants have been proposed as definitions and tests of machine intelligence. (2007; described in 2007 PDF [4])

5. Universal Intelligence ([4] 0712.3329v1.pdf, 2007)
   - The current paper explores universal intelligence in detail and its relation to mainstream views on human intelligence. (2007; described in 2007 PDF [4])

6. Qualitative Belief Propagation and Scenario-Based Reasoning ([5] 1304.1082v1.pdf, 1990)
   - Two new modes of explaining probabilistic reasoning were designed based on an empirical study of human strategies for uncertain reasoning. (1990; described in 1990 PDF [5])

7. Comprehensible Explanations of Probabilistic Reasoning and Bayesian Methods ([5] 1304.1082v1.pdf, 1990)
   - Comprehensible explanations of probabilistic reasoning are a prerequisite for wider acceptance of Bayesian methods in expert systems and decision support systems. (1990; described in 1990 PDF [5])
